Summer school will be held July 13-31, 2020, except Wednesdays to allow for cleaning. Due to concerns associated with the ongoing COVID-19 situation and guidance from the CDC and the Platte County Health Department, the number of students in attendance must be kept to a minimum. Please understand the limits we're working with and our desire to help as many kids as we can given those limits.

West Platte Graduation Postponed

West Platte’s 2020 Graduation Ceremony scheduled for Sunday, June 21, 7 PM at Rudolph Eskridge Stadium has been postponed to the previously released weather makeup date of Tuesday, June 23, 7 PM.

This decision was made after carefully monitoring numerous weather services, and consulting with Deputy Michael Macey with Platte County Emergency Management. The National Weather Service has also issued a Hazardous Weather Outlook for this evening. The safety of our graduates and all attendees supersedes all other considerations. In addition, under current health department stipulations, we do not have a viable safety alternative if a thunderstorm were to occur during the graduation ceremony. We apologize for any inconvenience and wish all fathers a wonderful Father’s Day.

West Platte Summer School 2020
Drivers Education Class

post_text: Synergy Services in Kansas City, MO, recently released the results of their Kindest Kansas Citian essay competition. This is an essay contest open to area Kindergarten through 12th grade students. Entrants are asked to define what kindness means to them, to identify an adult role model who "demonstrates kind, caring and respectful behavior that the students would like to emulate in their lives," and to "demonstrate the positive impact the nominee has had on the student's life." Out of almost 5,000 entries, sophomore Trent Taylor placed in the Top 100, and sophomore Savanah Hughes placed in the Top 20. Ms. Hughes and her nominee, Weston native and retired West Platte Elementary teacher Cindy Layton, will be recognized at the 30th Annual Kindest Kansas Citian Awards Celebration on Friday, May 1, 2020.

Making West Platte a Disease Ready Facility

Stay home when you are sick. You must be fever free for 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medication such as Tylenol or ibuprofen.

Cover your cough or sneeze completely with your elbow or a tissue. If you use a tissue, throw it in the trash and then wash your hands.

Avoid close contact with people who are sick. Six feet is considered close contact.

Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.

Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.

Attending extracurricular activities is at parent and guardian discretion unless otherwise noted due to the fluid nature of the COVID-19 coronavirus.

Help us keep your student and our community safe from infectious disease.

Here is a video from the CDC regarding proper hand-washing techniques:

Hail to the Chiefs!
What a season! For those of us who rooted for the Chiefs for many, many years, this is a big moment. Congratulations to the Kansas City Chiefs and the legions of fans who have passionately supported the ballclub through leaner times.

The West Platte School District will be open (weather permitting) when the Chiefs hold their celebratory parade.

For the Royals' parade in 2015 when they won the World Series, our student attendance was at, or above, 70%. Assuming a similar number in 2020 would suggest a number of our families may lack the work flexibility, child-care availability, or the interest to attend. That, in turn, would suggest we should be in school.

Of course, there will be several families who opt to attend the parade, and will want their kids with them. Have fun! All we ask, the same for any absence, is that we receive parental verification so the absence can be excused.

Thank you for your understanding and patience--from whatever point of view you may hold--and Go Chiefs!

post_text: On November 16th and December 21st FCCLA volunteered with the Salvation Army and the Ronald McDonald House. On the first Saturday of Christmas break, several students took time out to help serve food to families at the Ronald McDonald Family Room in Children's Mercy Hospital. Tin Kitchen was AMAZING and donated pulled pork and macaroni and cheese for the event!! Food was served for 3 hours and over 100 people were served. Everyone was so thankful and gracious. After serving food the group walked over to Union Station to look at the Christmas decorations and rode the streetcar to Power and Light to try Guy Fieri's new taco restaurant followed by dessert at Insomnia Cookies. Both places were also a new experience for all the students. The group has plans to volunteer at Wayside Waifs and the Noyes Home soon.

post_text: Saturday, November 23, the members of West Platte FBLA traveled to the Noyes Home for Children in Saint Joseph, Missouri. Brandon James, Katherine Tharp, and Victoria Norman led the project. The three organized a classroom contest to collect donations. These donations were then used to buy items for the home such as warm blankets, toiletries, and winter necessities. Around 30 students went to St. Joseph on a beautiful, sunny afternoon to spend time with the kids and to donate the goods bought. While at the home, students made the children's day by pushing them on swings, playing basketball, and making them smile. Throughout this time, the students were able to turn new faces into friends and learn about the kids' lives by interacting with them. West Platte FBLA has already planned another visit to the home in February of 2020, in which they aim to provide a familiar face and to give up their time to lighten children's days.

When each junior high athlete decided to participate in basketball, they not only decided to take on the challenge of learning or improving skill sets, schemes, and understandings of the game but also make the decision to be a part of a family: creating a brotherhood or sisterhood with their teammates. These young men and women will be together for the next four or five years of their lives at West Platte. They are and will grow as a family.

On November 26th at 7 A.M. the junior high boys basketball team served the junior high girls basketball team breakfast. These boys served the girls their food, drinks, and cleaned up afterward. We strengthened our chivalry and ability to take care of others and, hopefully, gained a deeper insight into the things in life that really mean the most.

Thanks for all the parent support,

-Coach McMahon and Coach Spencer

post_text: Today 4th-grade students learned about positive coping skills during their classroom counseling lesson. Students learned about 'Clay' problems vs 'Rock' problems. Mrs. Kelley taught students how they have the power to change 'Clay' problems and how they need to learn to cope with 'Rock' problems or things they can not in their lives. With the increase in anxiety and overall stress with children in today's society, it is important for children to be able to know how to cope in a positive way.
